value.title: Lenskart acquires AI computer vision startup TangoEye
value.excerpt: Eyewear retailer Lenskart has acquired Chennai-based TangoEye, an AI-based computer vision startup, which analyses CCTV recordings of stores to provide analytics, optimise customer flow and ensure proper adherence to all processes.

value.title: How computer vision increases productivity and sustainability in agriculture
value.excerpt: Computer vision is extending the human senses. Whether it’s allowing cars to drive themselves, automating production lines for safety and efficiency, or allowing us to unlock our phones with our faces, computer vision can help make human work more productive and accurate.

value.title: Three arrests after force trials facial recognition
value.excerpt: A police force which used live facial recognition (LFR) technology for the first time said it had led to three arrests, including one on suspicion of rape. Essex Police trialled LFR on high streets in Chelmsford and Southend this week.

value.title: Bat-inspired glasses help the blind & vision-impaired ‘see’ using sound
value.excerpt: Inspired by bats’ use of echolocation, researchers have developed smart glasses that transform visual information into unique sound representations that enhance the ability of blind and vision-impaired people to navigate their surroundings.

value.title: Massive facial recognition search engine now blocks searches for children’s faces
value.excerpt: PimEyes, a public search engine that uses facial recognition to match online photos of people, has banned searches of minors over concerns it endangers children, reports The New York Times.

value.title: Israel is using Amazon Rekognition to locate missing and dead
value.excerpt: Amazon Rekognition is being used in Israel to locate missing and dead after a deadly attack by Palestinian Hamas two weeks ago.

value.title: Israeli ‘Cyber War Room’ Uses Amazon Facial Recognition To Find Missing And Dead After Hamas Attack
value.excerpt: Amazon’s algorithms help identify at least 60 missing people in images and videos scraped from social media sites like Facebook and TikTok. Israel’s military is now running the project, its creators tell Forbes.

value.title: MIT researchers combine voice and object recognition in new model
value.excerpt: Researchers at MIT have developed a new system that combines voice and object recognition capable of identifying an object within an image given only a spoken description of that image.

value.title: Defect detection in high-resolution imagery using two-stage Amazon Rekognition Custom Labels models
value.excerpt: High-resolution imagery is very prevalent in today’s world, from satellite imagery to drones and DLSR cameras. From this imagery, we can capture damage due to natural disasters, anomalies in manufacturing equipment, or very small defects such as defects on printed circuit boards (PCBs) or semiconductors.

value.title: Met Police to keep using facial recognition on prolific shoplifters
value.excerpt: The Metropolitan Police plans to use facial recognition technology going forward to try to identify and arrest London's most prolific shoplifters. The technology maps facial features from CCTV stills against custody images in about 60 seconds. So far, 149 suspects have been identified from 302 CCTV stills with some wanted for multiple offences.
